instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Hello, I'm stuck as I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> which powers up fine on the charger alone but won't boot if the battery is connected.

I've tried a known good battery but still no change.

On USBC alone, F7000 is 13v
On Battery and USBC F7000 climbs from 11v to 12.96v and drops back in a cycle roughly every 6 seconds.
On battery alone F7000 sits around 10.6 and very slowly drops

Resistance on <RESISTOR>R7061</RESISTOR>/62 + <RESISTOR>R5438</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R5439</RESISTOR> are all as schematic.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> diode mode 
from pin 5 to pins 1-3 is .219v
from pin 4 to pins 1-3 is .634v

I'm not sure where to check from here

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Thank you for the reply 2informaticos.

<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> is reading 2.5 ohms while on the board

On a known good board, my multimeter shows 2.5 on that one also so I think my meter is just slightly out

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
threads.message:
The value is correct.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with battery alone (no charger)?
Did you check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 too?

Check for corrosion at J6951.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Yes I get 3.344v for <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> on battery alone

Yes I forgot to mention I checked <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and they're both as 1.3 ohms

J6951 looks clean inside and around it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
threads.message:
No, the MacBook came in with a non genuine battery but that seems to work. 
No history of liquid etc. Just wouldn't power on one day apparently.

I disconnected the battery and tried with just the charger and it turned on as if nothing had happened. reconnected the battery and two others and it won't start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Start with charger only and connect J6951 once logged into macOS.
Tight battery screw first, of course.
Check if battery is detected correctly then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not working if battery connected [SOLVED]
threads.message:
Well thats weird. 

I connected the battery and charger but not J6951, booted to MacOS and logged in.
I connected J6951 but it didn't see the battery

I left it all connected and hit restart, on once restarted, it sees the battery and is charging it.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on F7000 very slowly creeped up to 12.22v

If I unplug the charger, it stays on the battery perfectly with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating between 9.5v-10.8v

If I plug the charger back in, it begins charging again 2.7a and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> slows climbs back to 12.2v

It will now start on the battery alone.
